ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Discussion and insight into literature surrounding epidemics. How authors craft the narrative and influence how we perceive plagues.
I learned how to discuss literature about plague, whether metaphorical or literal, in terms of its social, political, and personal commentary.
Comprehensive understanding of numerous seminal works from throughout history, critical lens applied to the metaphors, stigma, and cultural consensuses surrounding multiple illnesses
Better writing techniques, how to develop and draft my ideas better, more concise writing

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great discussions and a good variety of novels. Read a book a week and three papers throughout the course. I think the papers could have been spaced out through the course a little better but that's about it. Overall, very fun and informative class.
Professor Berger chose engaging, comprehensive texts for us to discuss, and paced the workload well. The size of the class was perfect for discussion, and I looked forward to each week.
Course covers a lot of really interesting and diverse content! Zombie week was awesome! Perhaps a bit less reading per week

I enjoyed the trajectory of this course, as it allowed me to dedicate each week to exploring a new facet of plague literature and sharing those thoughts with my peers. However, perhaps having two assignments per paper, one being the first draft and the other the final draft, would be helpful for getting feedback on papers and editing them.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, very interesting content and engaging discussions.
Yes, I would, if they are interested in the texts on the syllabus.
Yes! Super awesome for anyone looking for small, discussion-oriented seminar and who is interested in the intersections between literature, art, and infectious disease

Yes; this course is truly unlike any other subject area Ive studied before. The simple term plague means several other things to me now after this semester than it did at the beginning of it. It will encourage students to think differently about such a vast and intersectional subject in literature.
